15#ifndef DNS_CLIENT_H
16#define DNS_CLIENT_H 1
17
18/*****
19 ***** Module Info
20 *****/
21
22/*! \file
23 *
24 * \brief
25 * The DNS client module provides convenient programming interfaces to various
26 * DNS services, such as name resolution with or without DNSSEC validation or
27 * dynamic DNS update. This module is primarily expected to be used by other
28 * applications than BIND9-related ones that need such advanced DNS features.
29 *
30 * MP:
31 *\li In the typical usage of this module, application threads will not share
32 * the same data structures created and manipulated in this module.
33 * However, the module still ensures appropriate synchronization of such
34 * data structures.
35 *
36 * Resources:
37 *\li TBS
38 *
39 * Security:
40 *\li This module does not handle any low-level data directly, and so no
41 * security issue specific to this module is anticipated.
42 */
43
44#include <isc/event.h>
45#include <isc/sockaddr.h>
46
47#include <dns/tsig.h>
48#include <dns/types.h>
49
50#include <dst/dst.h>
51
52typedef enum {
53 updateop_none = 0,
54 updateop_add = 1,
55 updateop_delete = 2,
56 updateop_exist = 3,
57 updateop_notexist = 4,
58 updateop_max = 5
59} dns_client_updateop_t;
60
61ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
62
63/***
64 *** Types
65 ***/
66
67/*%
68 * Optional flags for dns_client_create(x).
69 */
70/*%< Enable caching resolution results (experimental). */
71#define DNS_CLIENTCREATEOPT_USECACHE 0x8000
72
73/*%
74 * Optional flags for dns_client_(start)resolve.
75 */
76/*%< Do not return DNSSEC data (e.g. RRSIGS) with response. */
77#define DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NODNSSEC 0x01
78/*%< Allow running external context. */
79#define DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_ALLOWRUN 0x02
80/*%< Don't validate responses. */
81#define DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NOVALIDATE 0x04
82/*%< Don't set the CD flag on upstream queries. */
83#define DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NOCDFLAG 0x08
84/*%< Use TCP transport. */
85#define DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_TCP 0x10
86
87/*%
88 * Optional flags for dns_client_(start)request.
89 */
90/*%< Allow running external context. */
91#define DNS_CLIENTREQOPT_ALLOWRUN 0x01
92/*%< Use TCP transport. */
93#define DNS_CLIENTREQOPT_TCP 0x02
94
95/*%
96 * Optional flags for dns_client_(start)update.
97 */
98/*%< Allow running external context. */
99#define DNS_CLIENTUPDOPT_ALLOWRUN 0x01
100/*%< Use TCP transport. */
101#define DNS_CLIENTUPDOPT_TCP 0x02
102
103/*%
104 * View name used in dns_client.
105 */
106#define DNS_CLIENTVIEW_NAME "_dnsclient"
107
108/*%
109 * A dns_clientresevent_t is sent when name resolution performed by a client
110 * completes. 'result' stores the result code of the entire resolution
111 * procedure. 'vresult' specifically stores the result code of DNSSEC
112 * validation if it is performed. When name resolution successfully completes,
113 * 'answerlist' is typically non empty, containing answer names along with
114 * RRsets. It is the receiver's responsibility to free this list by calling
115 * dns_client_freeresanswer() before freeing the event structure.
116 */
117typedef struct dns_clientresevent {
118 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(struct dns_clientresevent);
119 isc_result_t result;
120 isc_result_t vresult;
121 dns_namelist_t answerlist;
122} dns_clientresevent_t; /* too long? */
123
124/*%
125 * Status of a dynamic update procedure.
126 */
127typedef enum {
128 dns_clientupdatestate_prepare, /*%< no updates have been sent */
129 dns_clientupdatestate_sent, /*%< updates were sent, no response */
130 dns_clientupdatestate_done /*%< update was sent and succeeded */
131} dns_clientupdatestate_t;
132
133/*%
134 * A dns_clientreqevent_t is sent when a DNS request is completed by a client.
135 * 'result' stores the result code of the entire transaction.
136 * If the transaction is successfully completed but the response packet cannot
137 * be parsed, 'result' will store the result code of dns_message_parse().
138 * If the response packet is received, 'rmessage' will contain the response
139 * message, whether it is successfully parsed or not.
140 */
141typedef struct dns_clientreqevent {
142 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(struct dns_clientreqevent);
143 isc_result_t result;
144 dns_message_t *rmessage;
145} dns_clientreqevent_t; /* too long? */
146
147/*%
148 * A dns_clientupdateevent_t is sent when dynamic update performed by a client
149 * completes. 'result' stores the result code of the entire update procedure.
150 * 'state' specifies the status of the update procedure when this event is
151 * sent. This can be used as a hint by the receiver to determine whether
152 * the update attempt was ever made. In particular, if the state is
153 * dns_clientupdatestate_prepare, the receiver can be sure that the requested
154 * update was not applied.
155 */
156typedef struct dns_clientupdateevent {
157 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(struct dns_clientupdateevent);
158 isc_result_t result;
159 dns_clientupdatestate_t state;
160} dns_clientupdateevent_t; /* too long? */
161
162isc_result_t
163dns_client_create(dns_client_t **clientp, unsigned int options);
164
165isc_result_t
166dns_client_createx(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_appctx_t *actx,
167 isc_taskmgr_t *taskmgr, isc_socketmgr_t *socketmgr,
168 isc_timermgr_t *timermgr, unsigned int options,
169 dns_client_t **clientp, const isc_sockaddr_t *localaddr4,
170 const isc_sockaddr_t *localaddr6);
171/*%<
172 * Create a DNS client. These functions create a new client object with
173 * minimal internal resources such as the default 'view' for the IN class and
174 * IPv4/IPv6 dispatches for the view.
175 *
176 * dns_client_createx() takes 'manager' arguments so that the caller can
177 * control the behavior of the client through the underlying event framework.
178 * On the other hand, dns_client_create() simplifies the interface and creates
179 * the managers internally. A DNS client object created via
180 * dns_client_create() is expected to be used by an application that only needs
181 * simple synchronous services or by a thread-based application.
182 *
183 * dns_client_createx2 takes two additional parameters, 'localaddr4' and
184 * 'localaddr6', to specify the local address to use for each family. If
185 * both are set to NULL, then wildcard addresses will be used for both
186 * families. If only one is NULL, then the other address will be used
187 * as the local address, and the other protocol family will not be used.
188 *
189 * If the DNS_CLIENTCREATEOPT_USECACHE flag is set in 'options',
190 * dns_client_create(x) will create a cache database with the view.
191 *
192 * Requires:
193 *
194 *\li 'mctx' is a valid memory context.
195 *
196 *\li 'actx' is a valid application context.
197 *
198 *\li 'taskmgr' is a valid task manager.
199 *
200 *\li 'socketmgr' is a valid socket manager.
201 *
202 *\li 'timermgr' is a valid timer manager.
203 *
204 *\li clientp != NULL && *clientp == NULL.
205 *
206 * Returns:
207 *
208 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
209 *
210 *\li Anything else Failure.
211 */
212
213void
214dns_client_destroy(dns_client_t **clientp);
215/*%<
216 * Destroy 'client'.
217 *
218 * Requires:
219 *
220 *\li '*clientp' is a valid client.
221 *
222 * Ensures:
223 *
224 *\li *clientp == NULL.
225 */
226
227isc_result_t
228dns_client_setservers(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
229 const dns_name_t *name_space, isc_sockaddrlist_t *addrs);
230/*%<
231 * Specify a list of addresses of recursive name servers that the client will
232 * use for name resolution. A view for the 'rdclass' class must be created
233 * beforehand. If 'name_space' is non NULL, the specified server will be used
234 * if and only if the query name is a subdomain of 'name_space'. When servers
235 * for multiple 'name_space's are provided, and a query name is covered by
236 * more than one 'name_space', the servers for the best (longest) matching
237 * name_space will be used. If 'name_space' is NULL, it works as if
238 * dns_rootname (.) were specified.
239 *
240 * Requires:
241 *
242 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
243 *
244 *\li 'name_space' is NULL or a valid name.
245 *
246 *\li 'addrs' != NULL.
247 *
248 * Returns:
249 *
250 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
251 *
252 *\li Anything else Failure.
253 */
254
255isc_result_t
256dns_client_clearservers(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
257 const dns_name_t *name_space);
258/*%<
259 * Remove configured recursive name servers for the 'rdclass' and 'name_space'
260 * from the client. See the description of dns_client_setservers() for
261 * the requirements about 'rdclass' and 'name_space'.
262 *
263 * Requires:
264 *
265 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
266 *
267 *\li 'name_space' is NULL or a valid name.
268 *
269 * Returns:
270 *
271 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
272 *
273 *\li Anything else Failure.
274 */
275
276isc_result_t
277dns_client_setdlv(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
278 const char *dlvname);
279/*%<
280 * Specify a name to use for DNSSEC lookaside validation.
281 * If a trusted key has been added for that name, then DLV will be
282 * used during validation. If 'dlvname' is NULL, then DLV will no
283 * longer be used for this client.
284 *
285 * Requires:
286 *
287 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
288 *
289 * Returns:
290 *
291 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
292 *
293 *\li Anything else Failure.
294 */
295
296isc_result_t
297dns_client_resolve(dns_client_t *client, const dns_name_t *name,
298 dns_rdataclass_t rdclass, dns_rdatatype_t type,
299 unsigned int options, dns_namelist_t *namelist);
300
301isc_result_t
302dns_client_startresolve(dns_client_t *client, const dns_name_t *name,
303 dns_rdataclass_t rdclass, dns_rdatatype_t type,
304 unsigned int options, isc_task_t *task,
305 isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg,
306 dns_clientrestrans_t **transp);
307/*%<
308 * Perform name resolution for 'name', 'rdclass', and 'type'.
309 *
310 * If any trusted keys are configured and the query name is considered to
311 * belong to a secure zone, these functions also validate the responses
312 * using DNSSEC by default. If the DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NOVALIDATE flag is set
313 * in 'options', DNSSEC validation is disabled regardless of the configured
314 * trusted keys or the query name. With DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NODNSSEC
315 * DNSSEC data is not returned with response. DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_NOCDFLAG
316 * disables the CD flag on queries, DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_TCP switches to
317 * the TCP (vs. UDP) transport.
318 *
319 * dns_client_resolve() provides a synchronous service. This function starts
320 * name resolution internally and blocks until it completes. On success,
321 * 'namelist' will contain a list of answer names, each of which has
322 * corresponding RRsets. The caller must provide a valid empty list, and
323 * is responsible for freeing the list content via dns_client_freeresanswer().
324 * If the name resolution fails due to an error in DNSSEC validation,
325 * dns_client_resolve() returns the result code indicating the validation
326 * error. Otherwise, it returns the result code of the entire resolution
327 * process, either success or failure.
328 *
329 * It is typically expected that the client object passed to
330 * dns_client_resolve() was created via dns_client_create() and has its own
331 * managers and contexts. However, if the DNS_CLIENTRESOPT_ALLOWRUN flag is
332 * set in 'options', this function performs the synchronous service even if
333 * it does not have its own manager and context structures.
334 *
335 * dns_client_startresolve() is an asynchronous version of dns_client_resolve()
336 * and does not block. When name resolution is completed, 'action' will be
337 * called with the argument of a 'dns_clientresevent_t' object, which contains
338 * the resulting list of answer names (on success). On return, '*transp' is
339 * set to an opaque transaction ID so that the caller can cancel this
340 * resolution process.
341 *
342 * Requires:
343 *
344 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
345 *
346 *\li 'addrs' != NULL.
347 *
348 *\li 'name' is a valid name.
349 *
350 *\li 'namelist' != NULL and is not empty.
351 *
352 *\li 'task' is a valid task.
353 *
354 *\li 'transp' != NULL && *transp == NULL;
355 *
356 * Returns:
357 *
358 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
359 *
360 *\li Anything else Failure.
361 */
362
363void
364dns_client_cancelresolve(dns_clientrestrans_t *trans);
365/*%<
366 * Cancel an ongoing resolution procedure started via
367 * dns_client_startresolve().
368 *
369 * Notes:
370 *
371 *\li If the resolution procedure has not completed, post its CLIENTRESDONE
372 * event with a result code of #ISC_R_CANCELED.
373 *
374 * Requires:
375 *
376 *\li 'trans' is a valid transaction ID.
377 */
378
379void
380dns_client_destroyrestrans(dns_clientrestrans_t **transp);
381/*%<
382 * Destroy name resolution transaction state identified by '*transp'.
383 *
384 * Requires:
385 *
386 *\li '*transp' is a valid transaction ID.
387 *
388 *\li The caller has received the CLIENTRESDONE event (either because the
389 * resolution completed or because dns_client_cancelresolve() was called).
390 *
391 * Ensures:
392 *
393 *\li *transp == NULL.
394 */
395
396void
397dns_client_freeresanswer(dns_client_t *client, dns_namelist_t *namelist);
398/*%<
399 * Free resources allocated for the content of 'namelist'.
400 *
401 * Requires:
402 *
403 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
404 *
405 *\li 'namelist' != NULL.
406 */
407
408isc_result_t
409dns_client_addtrustedkey(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
410 const dns_name_t *keyname, isc_buffer_t *keydatabuf);
411/*%<
412 * Add a DNSSEC trusted key for the 'rdclass' class. A view for the 'rdclass'
413 * class must be created beforehand. 'keyname' is the DNS name of the key,
414 * and 'keydatabuf' stores the resource data of the key.
415 *
416 * Requires:
417 *
418 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
419 *
420 *\li 'keyname' is a valid name.
421 *
422 *\li 'keydatabuf' is a valid buffer.
423 *
424 * Returns:
425 *
426 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
427 *
428 *\li Anything else Failure.
429 */
430
431isc_result_t
432dns_client_request(dns_client_t *client, dns_message_t *qmessage,
433 dns_message_t *rmessage, const isc_sockaddr_t *server,
434 unsigned int options, unsigned int parseoptions,
435 dns_tsec_t *tsec, unsigned int timeout,
436 unsigned int udptimeout, unsigned int udpretries);
437
438isc_result_t
439dns_client_startrequest(dns_client_t *client, dns_message_t *qmessage,
440 dns_message_t *rmessage, const isc_sockaddr_t *server,
441 unsigned int options, unsigned int parseoptions,
442 dns_tsec_t *tsec, unsigned int timeout,
443 unsigned int udptimeout, unsigned int udpretries,
444 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg,
445 dns_clientreqtrans_t **transp);
446
447/*%<
448 * Send a DNS request containig a query message 'query' to 'server'.
449 *
450 * 'parseoptions' will be used when the response packet is parsed, and will be
451 * passed to dns_message_parse() via dns_request_getresponse(). See
452 * dns_message_parse() for more details.
453 *
454 * 'tsec' is a transaction security object containing, e.g. a TSIG key for
455 * authenticating the request/response transaction. This is optional and can
456 * be NULL, in which case this library performs the transaction without any
457 * transaction authentication.
458 *
459 * 'timeout', 'udptimeout', and 'udpretries' are passed to
460 * dns_request_createvia3(). See dns_request_createvia3() for more details.
461 *
462 * dns_client_request() provides a synchronous service. This function sends
463 * the request and blocks until a response is received. On success,
464 * 'rmessage' will contain the response message. The caller must provide a
465 * valid initialized message.
466 *
467 * It is usually expected that the client object passed to
468 * dns_client_request() was created via dns_client_create() and has its own
469 * managers and contexts. However, if the DNS_CLIENTREQOPT_ALLOWRUN flag is
470 * set in 'options', this function performs the synchronous service even if
471 * it does not have its own manager and context structures.
472 *
473 * dns_client_startrequest() is an asynchronous version of dns_client_request()
474 * and does not block. When the transaction is completed, 'action' will be
475 * called with the argument of a 'dns_clientreqevent_t' object, which contains
476 * the response message (on success). On return, '*transp' is set to an opaque
477 * transaction ID so that the caller can cancel this request.
478 *
479 * DNS_CLIENTREQOPT_TCP switches to the TCP (vs. UDP) transport.
480 *
481 * Requires:
482 *
483 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
484 *
485 *\li 'qmessage' and 'rmessage' are valid initialized message.
486 *
487 *\li 'server' is a valid socket address structure.
488 *
489 *\li 'task' is a valid task.
490 *
491 *\li 'transp' != NULL && *transp == NULL;
492 *
493 * Returns:
494 *
495 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
496 *
497 *\li Anything else Failure.
498 *
499 *\li Any result that dns_message_parse() can return.
500 */
501
502void
503dns_client_cancelrequest(dns_clientreqtrans_t *transp);
504/*%<
505 * Cancel an ongoing DNS request procedure started via
506 * dns_client_startrequest().
507 *
508 * Notes:
509 *
510 *\li If the request procedure has not completed, post its CLIENTREQDONE
511 * event with a result code of #ISC_R_CANCELED.
512 *
513 * Requires:
514 *
515 *\li 'trans' is a valid transaction ID.
516 */
517
518void
519dns_client_destroyreqtrans(dns_clientreqtrans_t **transp);
520/*%
521 * Destroy DNS request transaction state identified by '*transp'.
522 *
523 * Requires:
524 *
525 *\li '*transp' is a valid transaction ID.
526 *
527 *\li The caller has received the CLIENTREQDONE event (either because the
528 * request completed or because dns_client_cancelrequest() was called).
529 *
530 * Ensures:
531 *
532 *\li *transp == NULL.
533 */
534
535isc_result_t
536dns_client_update(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
537 const dns_name_t *zonename, dns_namelist_t *prerequisites,
538 dns_namelist_t *updates, isc_sockaddrlist_t *servers,
539 dns_tsec_t *tsec, unsigned int options);
540
541isc_result_t
542dns_client_startupdate(dns_client_t *client, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
543 const dns_name_t *zonename,
544 dns_namelist_t *prerequisites,
545 dns_namelist_t *updates, isc_sockaddrlist_t *servers,
546 dns_tsec_t *tsec, unsigned int options,
547 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg,
548 dns_clientupdatetrans_t **transp);
549/*%<
550 * Perform DNS dynamic update for 'updates' of the 'rdclass' class with
551 * optional 'prerequisites'.
552 *
553 * 'updates' are a list of names with associated RRsets to be updated.
554 *
555 * 'prerequisites' are a list of names with associated RRsets corresponding to
556 * the prerequisites of the updates. This is optional and can be NULL, in
557 * which case the prerequisite section of the update message will be empty.
558 *
559 * Both 'updates' and 'prerequisites' must be constructed as specified in
560 * RFC2136.
561 *
562 * 'zonename' is the name of the zone in which the updated names exist.
563 * This is optional and can be NULL. In this case, these functions internally
564 * identify the appropriate zone through some queries for the SOA RR starting
565 * with the first name in prerequisites or updates.
566 *
567 * 'servers' is a list of authoritative servers to which the update message
568 * should be sent. This is optional and can be NULL. In this case, these
569 * functions internally identify the appropriate primary server name and its
570 * addresses through some queries for the SOA RR (like the case of zonename)
571 * and supplemental A/AAAA queries for the server name.
572 * Note: The client module generally assumes the given addresses are of the
573 * primary server of the corresponding zone. It will work even if a secondary
574 * server address is specified as long as the server allows update forwarding,
575 * it is generally discouraged to include secondary server addresses unless
576 * there's strong reason to do so.
577 *
578 * 'tsec' is a transaction security object containing, e.g. a TSIG key for
579 * authenticating the update transaction (and the supplemental query/response
580 * transactions if the server is specified). This is optional and can be
581 * NULL, in which case the library tries the update without any transaction
582 * authentication.
583 *
584 * It is typically expected that the client object passed to
585 * dns_client_update() was created via dns_client_create() and has its own
586 * managers and contexts. However, if the DNS_CLIENTUPDOPT_ALLOWRUN flag is
587 * set in 'options', this function performs the synchronous service even if
588 * it does not have its own manager and context structures.
589 *
590 * dns_client_update() provides a synchronous service. This function blocks
591 * until the entire update procedure completes, including the additional
592 * queries when necessary.
593 *
594 * dns_client_startupdate() is an asynchronous version of dns_client_update().
595 * It immediately returns (typically with *transp being set to a non-NULL
596 * pointer), and performs the update procedure through a set of internal
597 * events. All transactions including the additional query exchanges are
598 * performed as a separate event, so none of these events cause blocking
599 * operation. When the update procedure completes, the specified function
600 * 'action' will be called with the argument of a 'dns_clientupdateevent_t'
601 * structure. On return, '*transp' is set to an opaque transaction ID so that
602 * the caller can cancel this update process.
603 *
604 * DNS_CLIENTUPDOPT_TCP switches to the TCP (vs. UDP) transport.
605 *
606 * Requires:
607 *
608 *\li 'client' is a valid client.
609 *
610 *\li 'updates' != NULL.
611 *
612 *\li 'task' is a valid task.
613 *
614 *\li 'transp' != NULL && *transp == NULL;
615 *
616 * Returns:
617 *
618 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS On success.
619 *
620 *\li Anything else Failure.
621 */
622
623void
624dns_client_cancelupdate(dns_clientupdatetrans_t *trans);
625/*%<
626 * Cancel an ongoing dynamic update procedure started via
627 * dns_client_startupdate().
628 *
629 * Notes:
630 *
631 *\li If the update procedure has not completed, post its UPDATEDONE
632 * event with a result code of #ISC_R_CANCELED.
633 *
634 * Requires:
635 *
636 *\li 'trans' is a valid transaction ID.
637 */
638
639void
640dns_client_destroyupdatetrans(dns_clientupdatetrans_t **transp);
641/*%<
642 * Destroy dynamic update transaction identified by '*transp'.
643 *
644 * Requires:
645 *
646 *\li '*transp' is a valid transaction ID.
647 *
648 *\li The caller has received the UPDATEDONE event (either because the
649 * update completed or because dns_client_cancelupdate() was called).
650 *
651 * Ensures:
652 *
653 *\li *transp == NULL.
654 */
655
656isc_result_t
657dns_client_updaterec(dns_client_updateop_t op, const dns_name_t *owner,
658 dns_rdatatype_t type, dns_rdata_t *source,
659 dns_ttl_t ttl, dns_name_t *target,
660 dns_rdataset_t *rdataset, dns_rdatalist_t *rdatalist,
661 dns_rdata_t *rdata, isc_mem_t *mctx);
662/*%<
663 * TBD
664 */
665
666void
667dns_client_freeupdate(dns_name_t **namep);
668/*%<
669 * TBD
670 */
671
672isc_mem_t *
673dns_client_mctx(dns_client_t *client);
674
675ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
676
677#endif /* DNS_CLIENT_H */
